title: Ubuntu Application Switcher
description: Canonical Ltd. started developing Ubuntu for mobile devices. As part of this effort, I designed and prototyped an application switcher for Ubuntu Touch OS.

content.title: The UX Challenge
content.text:
Application switching is one of the most often performed tasks in both mobile and desktop operating systems. Hence it needs to be a fluid and frictionless interaction. For this project the main requirements were: 

‚Ä¢ Full convergence: the same switcher would need to work on phone, tablet and PC desktop. 
‚Ä¢ Needs to handle both windowed and non-windowed environments. 
‚Ä¢ Multiple workspace support needs to be taken into account. 
‚Ä¢ Needs to support all available input types: touch, pointer and keyboard. 
‚Ä¢ Single code base approach (stakeholder and engineering requirement). 
‚Ä¢ The existing design relying on stacked cards needs to be taken into consideration. 

 The main UX challenges:
 ‚Ä¢ How to create an adapting layout that transforms andcovers all use cases.
 ‚Ä¢ Creating consistent set of transitions and animations which would also be delightful to use and reinforce user‚Äôs metal model of the system.
 ‚Ä¢ Application window size can be arbitrary and vary between the windows simultaneously on the screen.
 ‚Ä¢ Horizontal space is limited but the design needs to scale to support 0-N application and 0-N workspaces.

content.title: The UX Approach
content.text:
Guiding design principles that helped in the design process:

 ‚Ä¢ Prefer subtle and unobtrusive animations to provide quick and consistent feeling across the use cases.
‚Ä¢ Utilise the screen real estate as well as possible and avoid overflow behind the screen edges.
‚Ä¢ Provide easily identifiable application info (card + icon + label).
‚Ä¢ Aim for full convergence: Same visual appearance, functionality and interactions across form factors, devices and input types.
‚Ä¢ Re-use existing Ubuntu design and visual patterns.

I wrote an interactive prototype to help in design.This turned out
to be invaluable approach that helped out to identify and solve many corner use cases. The prototype also worked as partial documentation for developers.

content.title: The final design
content.alt: An example image from the project.
content.caption: The same design and codebase works across phone, tablet and desktop form factors.
content.text:
The result layout is fully responsive that automatically adjusts its element sizes, margins and visibility while maintaining balanced look and feel. Application windows are cropped in to a square shape with suitable cropping algorithm and application icon and label were added to maximise application identifiability. The final design supports following functionality: 

 ‚Ä¢ Application switching. 
‚Ä¢ Closing applications 
‚Ä¢ Moving applications between workspaces 
‚Ä¢ Closing, reordering and merging workspaces 
‚Ä¢ Focusing on to another workspace.

content.title: Impact
content.text:
The converged switcher was part of Ubuntu 10.16 release as a default Unity 8 application switcher. 
The final implementation is essential part of a product that got awarded: üèÜ **Orange Award for Converged Computing** at Mobile World Congress 2017.

title: Accessible Version Control Change Indicators
description: Designing accessible change indicators for Visual Studio to enhance code management for developers with disabilities.

content.title: Project Overview
content.text: The code change indicators mark lines that have been modified, added, or deleted in the code file. The existing indicators in Visual Studio's version control system were not accessible for all users, and didn't provide the change type information being inconsistent with for example VS Code. I led the redesign work to ensure they were accessible and usable by all developers, regardless of their visual abilities.

content.title: UX Problem
content.caption: Emulation of how color blind users see the existing change indicators.
content.text:
‚Ä¢ The indicators had 2 visual states **changed-not saved (yellow bar)**, and **changed-saved (green bar)** represented only by color.
‚Ä¢ Different kinds of changes (addition, deletion, modification) don't have unique indicators.
‚Ä¢ Imparity with Visual Studio Code.
‚Ä¢  Not accessible for vision impaired users.
‚Ä¢ Color contrast ratio is not sufficient for passing WCAG standards.
‚Ä¢ Some vision impaired users can‚Äôt distinguish unsaved changes from saved changes.
‚Ä¢ The change margin indicators don‚Äôt follow the Git status.

content.title: Objectives
content.text:
‚Ä¢ Align implementation with other Microsoft products.
‚Ä¢ Follow more industry standard style for code change indicators.
‚Ä¢ Make sure that the new implementation is fully accessible and passes the WCAG rules and Microsoft Accessibility Standards.
‚Ä¢ New design needs to support Line Staging feature the was being designed in parallel.
‚Ä¢ Design for both light and dark themes.

content.title: Design Process
content.text: First we conducted user research and usability testing with developers with visual impairments to understand their needs and challenges with the existing indicators. Collaborated with accessibility experts to ensure compliance with accessibility standards and guidelines. I explored various design options, including patterns, shapes, and textures, to create indicators that were easily distinguishable by all users. I developed prototypes and shared those in the community feedback tickets and user testing. I refined the designs based on the feedback from users and experts.

content.title: Design Iterations
content.text: We went throught multiple design iterations to explore different visual representations. I tested various shapes, patterns, and color combinations to ensure that the indicators were easily distinguishable by all users. I also considered the overall aesthetics and how the new indicators would fit within the existing Visual Studio interface.

images.alt: Change indicator design iteration exploring various texture patterns to represent different change types.
images.caption: I explored varions texture patterns to represent different change types.

images.alt: Change indicator design iteration exploring various sign and character patterns to represent different change types.
images.caption: Also explored various sign and character patterns.
In iteration 3, users clearly preferred design concept C3.2 over the other presented options.
Iteration 4 was one of the most complex designs as it showed both change type and staging information. This was concluded too much information for users to process at once.

content.title: Final Design and Impact
content.text:
The final design was successfully implemented in Visual Studio 2022 version 17.3 and later. The design met the all the set objectives and received positive feedback from users, particularly those with visual impairments. 

 I received a patent award for the design work. 

Some users still preferred the old design due to familiarity, and we provided an option to switch back to the previous design if desired. Even then, the yellow and green color values were updated for better contrast and accessibility.

Visual Studio IDE had an existing Git experience that was outdated and not user-friendly. I led the redesign effort to create make it more intuitive, efficient, and accessible for all developers.

title: Ubuntu Touch Indicators
description: Gesture based indicator panel interactions for Ubuntu Touch OS.

content.title: The UX Challenge
content.text:
User testing had showed that the existing Ubuntu Touch indicators were suffering from several usability issues. My task was to re-design indicators and to fix following problems:

‚Ä¢  Users didn‚Äôt understand the connections between different UI elements.
‚Ä¢ Users struggled with the swipe down gesture and didn‚Äôt get the targeted menu open.
‚Ä¢ Users struggled navigating between open menus.
‚Ä¢ The current design didn‚Äôt handle overflow situation when there are more indicators than available space.

content.title: The UX Approach
content.text:
To handle the overflow **non-relevant indicators are hidden** in closed state. As soon as the opening gesture is started they become visible again and their menus are accessible. 

Indicator items expand once the gesture is started. Initial touch position provides **a horizontal anchor point** around which all expansions happen. This **ensures that the target item doesn‚Äôt move during the gesture**.

**Vertical expansion** provides space for the label. Expanded item acts as a clear navigation element when indicators are open. Now two unconnected elements from the previous design were combined to one meaningful element.

**Horizontal expansion provides space for more robust gesture** which was further enhanced with vertical velocity buffering and maximum vertical velocity threshold.

content.text: The new design retained all the good functionality from the old indicators while fixing all usability issues. The new indicator design was user tested multiple times and the results have been significantly better. It fullfilled the stakeholder expectations and also got great feedback from the actual Ubuntu phone users.

title: Figma Screen Reader Plugin
description: Figma plugin to increase design workshop accessibility and productivity.

content.title: The Challenge
content.text: I attended a workshop focused on identifying problems with programming tools and improving the user experience from the perspective of screen reader users. I interviewed users and tried to communicate the tools I had created to them. I noticed the difficulty in communication because the designs were visual presentations, while visually impaired users rely on a screen reader as their sole interface daily. Validating the designs and obtaining concrete feedback was challenging.

content.title: The Solution
content.text: I wanted to design a better process and tool for accessible communication of designs to all workshop participants. I developed a plugin for the Figma design software I was using, which acted as a connecting tissue between the design tool and the operating system‚Äôs (macOS or Windows) screen reader (Narrator, VoiceOver, NVDA, JAWS, etc). The tool allowed designer to specify screenreader anouncements (ARIA live regions) that were spoken aloud while the design was being interacted with.

images.caption: Create: Documentation on how to create screen reader annotations in Figma.

images.alt: Documentation screenshot showing how to play screen reader annotations in Figma.
images.caption: Play: Documentation on how to play screen reader annotations in Figma.

content.title: The Impact
content.text: The tool enabled more effective communication with visually impaired users, allowing us to receive concrete feedback on our solutions. This process strengthened empathy and collaboration with screen reader users and provided valuable insights into their specific needs. Personally, I gained extensive experience with screen readers, accessibility best practices, Copilot AI-assisted coding, Figma plugins, and the Vue front-end framework, which was new to me.
